pullRequest.body:
This PR defines an interactive unfolding tactic. It suggests a list of unfolds, and when you select one, it pastes a rewrite tactic of the form `rw [show current = unfolded from rfl]`.

This is part of #11768, which is a library rewrite tactic that also suggests the unfolds from this PR.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: awaiting-review

To make it easier to review, could you please add module docstrings (see [documentation guidelines](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html#header-comment)) to the two files you added and also add a test file (e.g. `test/interactiveUnfold.lean`) which showcases/tests the usages. You can e.g. use `#guard_msgs in`, see e.g. `test/rewrites.lean`.

### PR summary [d2df2f6150](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12016/commits/d2df2f6150e8804fd5af602ca29eb13c899f6770)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic | 2121 | 2127 | +6 (+0.28%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Lean.GoalsLocation`|2|
| `Mathlib.Lean.Meta.KAbstractPositions`|3|
| `Mathlib.Tactic`|6|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.Widget.InteractiveUnfold`|14|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ UnfoldComponent`
`+ elabUnfoldCommand`
`+ filteredUnfolds`
`+ isUserFriendly`
`+ kabstractIsTypeCorrect`
`+ kabstractPositions`
`+ location`
`+ mkRewrite`
`+ pasteString`
`+ pos`
`+ renderUnfolds`
`+ rootExpr`
`+ tacticString`
`+ unfoldProjDefaultInst?`
`+ viewKAbstractSubExpr`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

I've added two module docstrings, and updated the code for the newer version of lean.

I've added a test file which uses the testing command `#unfold?` instead of the tactic `unfold?` itself because it is difficult to test directly.

The shift-clicking behaviour you describe is expected, and it is a result of how shift-clicking works (so not my code). Each clickable expression has two states: clicked or not clicked. And clicking on it swaps the state. My tactic obtains the array of clicked positions in the order in which they were selected, and it only considers the last one.

The awkward thing is that if you select two expressions, one of which is inside another one, you have to look really closely to see that both of them have a blue highlight, and it almost looks like just the outer one has a highlight.

(I'll also be on holiday, starting on Friday :-))
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.

What should I expect for 
```lean
#unfold? Function.comp (fun x => 2*x) (fun y => 3*y) (2 + 3)
```

The tactic is written such that all suggestions are in `whnfCore` normal form (I should mention this in the module docstring). So after the first unfold, we get `2*(3*(2+3))`. Then the next unfold will make this into `Nat.mul 2 (3*(2+3))`, and the next unfold will do natural number evaluation, turning this into `30`. So I expect those three suggestions.

Do you think it would be an improvement to not show the `Nat.mul` term in the case where natural number evaluation applies?

No, I was thinking you unfold somewhere else than the head symbol but that is probably a bad thing to do since it diverges from the conventions. 

I think this is nice and would approve but haven't touched the widget framework. It would nice if @PatrickMassot or someone else who has experience there could take a quick look at that part.

The widget part looks fine to me. We should really do something to reduce the copy-paste, but I guess this is a question for @Vtec234. 

However, the file position is not what Iâ€¯expected. All other similar tactics are in Tactic/Widget.

It would also be nice to detect when there is no unfold suggestion but the expression head is a structure with one field. For instance in topology, the widget will currently say something useful when pointed at `IsOpenMap` but not when pointed at `Continuous`. For people who donâ€™t know everything about Mathlib implementation details this is probably very confusing. This can be a follow up PR of course.
@JovanGerb can you move the file as Patrick suggests?

Thanks! 

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10016345301/job/27689163551)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10016345301/job/27689163693)

Looks good to me!

There's one question about mvar-context I didn't understand and a few stylistic comments, but I think this PR is written very cleanly and ready for delegation by a maintainer.

One further question:

```lean
example : 1 âˆˆ A âˆª B := by
  unfold?
  sorry
```
If I shift-click around (e.g. click on `âˆˆ`, `âˆª`, `âˆˆ`) then I have to click twice on `âˆˆ` to change this third time (and after that only every second shift-click changes the `unfold?` message). Do you observe that, too? Anyways, I can't tell if that's caused by your code or something else, and I don't think this is a crucial bug that would prevent merging.

I'll leave you some time to address the comments above (and I might be on holidays the next few days), but I'd put the PR on the `maintainer merge` queue afterwards.

```suggestion
#unfold? (0 : Rat)
```

```suggestion
#unfold? (42 : â„š)
```

```suggestion
#unfold? (fun x => x) (1 + 1)
```

```suggestion
#unfold? 3 âˆˆ ({1, 2, 3} : Set â„•)
```

```suggestion
#unfold? 5 / 3
```

```suggestion
#unfold? 1 + 1
```

```suggestion
      match e with
      | .app fn arg                  => visit fn pos.pushAppFn
                                    >=> visit arg pos.pushAppArg
      | .mdata _ expr                => visit expr pos
      | .proj _ _ struct             => visit struct pos.pushProj
      | .letE _ type value body _    => visit type pos.pushLetVarType
                                    >=> visit value pos.pushLetValue
                                    >=> visit body pos.pushLetBody
      | .lam _ binderType body _     => visit binderType pos.pushBindingDomain
                                    >=> visit body pos.pushBindingBody
      | .forallE _ binderType body _ => visit binderType pos.pushBindingDomain
                                    >=> visit body pos.pushBindingBody
      | _                            => pure
```
Optional. Personally, I find it slightly easier to read using the names of the arguments.

```suggestion
  /-- The main loop that loops through all subexpressions -/
```
I don't understand what `setMCtx` is for since it looks to me that `mctx` is defined only once outside the loop and never modified. Can you quickly explain?

Yes, `isDefEq` can change the `mctx` if it succeeds. In particular if you run `isDefEq` on `?m =?= 5`, then after it returns `true`, the assignment `?m := 5` is added to the `MetavarContext`.

The (new) behaviour of `kabstract` is that it only keeps the `MetavarContext` for expressions that are abstracted, and not the ones that are skipped. This means that it is possible to rewrite in either of the two positions of `1+2+3` using `add_comm`, by setting the position to be either 1 or 2. Resetting the `MetavarContext` is important, because if we choose position 2, we want to forget the assignments of `?a` and `?b` after unifying `?a + ?b` with `1 + 2 + 3`, so that later we can unify it with `1 + 2`.

I see, thank you! Didn't know how `isDefEq` works.

Maybe a comment like ``-- reset `mctx` as `isDefEq` might change the context`` would help somebody like me?

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
It allows you to shift-click on an expression in the goal, and then it suggests rewrites to replace
```

```suggestion
`HAdd.hAdd` in `1+1` actually first unfolds into `Add.add`, but this is not very useful,
```

```suggestion
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: interactive `unfold?` tactic
